name: The Average Everyday Adventures of Samantha Browne
description: An interactive story about a painfully introverted college student who must find a way to make some oatmeal in the communal kitchen of her dorm. One simple task, can you help her complete it?
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 Processor: 2+ Ghz Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: Intel 3000HD or greater Sound Card: Optional (but recommended)

reviews.review_text: “Nobody realizes that some people expend tremendous energy merely to be normal.” - Albert Camus   It is more than true that casual interactions of everyday life and trivial anecdotes of one random conversation end up being tremendous tests of courage and regulation for some people. Nowadays, it is called as Social Anxiety Disorder. I have never been one of those, yet I had my mood swings, my antisocial moments and most invested 'me-times' as any other introvert. I most prefer reading a book, watching a movie or sipping a glass of drink all by my lonesome to thrilling adventures of a social butterfly. I can - to a degree, relate to this.   The Average Everyday Adventures of Samantha Browne  features a young university student living on a remote dorm - who isn't also only an introvert, but one that suffers from SAD most assuredly. This short, relatable visual novel is Samantha's challenge to make herself a cup of oatmeal porridge in the middle of the night at her dorm's commune kitchen. She first has to gather courage to get out of her bed and leave her room, still her drumming heart to walk down the hallway, brave all possible social encounters around and manage to cook herself a cup of oatmeal before returning victorious to the safety of her room. It is a quest nonetheless.  Visuals are all hand-drawn in a humorous graphic novel style, with cheesy anecdotes scattered, carrying proper exaggerations to illuminate Samantha's own train of thought better. I must say sound effects are another well done detail to enhance the mood. As a character, Samantha isn't impressive or even remotely interesting but she is real. She is a girl who lives in a dorm and has genuine hardship to get herself a cup of oatmeal only. She fears of judgment and suffers from constant social insecurity, constantly trying to plan what to do, how to react, what to say or not to avoid any kind of awkwardness. It is there. It is very real, even though it is not logical at all, and this game manages to enact a trivial errand as a perilous quest most successfully.  For the gameplay mechanics, it is mostly a visual novel with some choice options. You are to watch for Samantha's anxiety meter and manage to lead her through her quest and back to her room with a cup of edible oatmeal. That's all. I'll present a clue to help your heroine: sometimes not making a choice and waiting things out is a choice.  The game is free here on Steam for your enjoyment, and it also carries some humorous anecdotes just as it has its contemplative nature. Look around, you'll notice Samantha's kindred all around you in your daily life; waiting on the bus line, sitting at your desk at school or the workplace, at the movies... They are the people that would sweat and blush before asking you directions to a place. Treat them with kindness, and you may get surprised by them.  Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page  here  - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

Sorry, but I can’t recommend this game. Yes, I understand it’s about anxiety and dealing with its daily challenges (I myself suffer from anxiety disorder — went to various doctors and I’m on treatment), where when simply cooking a meal might be a hard thing to do. But Samantha is an annoying MC, and this game also fails to help people who don’t suffer from this condition to understand what it feels like.   3/10.
'Social anxiety as a VN game'

I have mixed feelings. Overall, for a free game, a short time filler, I'd give it a 3.5/5  It's nicely put together, it shows how some people can think when they have anxiety. Not too long. I finally managed to make the oatmeal on my third attempt. I was incredibly pleased with myself, until I saw there were two more achievements to get.    I have anxiety, so I can understand how she feels with a lot of the stuff, but this was really frustrating... ('though maybe that's the point?) because- (minor I guess, but still) spoilers-    she got to uni but doesn't know how to use a kettle?? What the hell? What english person gets to 18/19 without using a kettle or seeing someone use one or even understanding how it works? she went to uni with no cooking equipment except a mug & spoon? she's downright rude when there's no need to say anything. No wonder her flatmates dislike her. she knows she has problems with a shared kitchen but doesn't have any food in her room that she can eat? and why isn't she on meds?!

It's fun to be in someone else's head for a little while.  In this game, you are in the head of a really paranoid and judgemental North American girl who has come to England to attend university but doesn't know things like the basics of how to live, and also thinks terrible things about her neighbours, so she can't ask them for help.   Sounds unbelievable? I met people like this in university. It was a university where you needed to be very very clever to get in, too. And yet... ah. People who put food directly onto cooking rings because they thought the pan was unnecessary. People who decided to boil eggs in the microwave. The numerous fire alarms set off by burnt toast.  Calm down, Samantha Browne! You can get your own kettle and microwave and water jug from Argos or Wilkos or something for under £50 and never need to leave the room to use the kitchen!  I fully expect that if there is a sequel to this, she'll try to do her laundry. Or try using the communal bathroom facilities!

This is, by far, the best Visual Novel I've ever played. A true and accurate depiction of how a simple everyday task may be an impossible thing to do for a person with social anxiety. It's a well-written story, the text is easy to read and easy to understand when it's not your native language, maybe a little short but probably one of the reasons why it's free. I really hope there will be another adventure of Samantha one day, longer than this one!

This may have worked in a different setting. For example, maybe she lives at home with a suffocating parent and going to the kitchen would draw attention and force you into a long conversation about 'what are you going to do with your life' which makes me anxious just thinking about it. But in a college setting, I just kept thinking 'how does she even get to class?' So what, there are people in the kitchen, none of them seem at all inclined to talk to her, which is how I prefer things with my social anxiety. If they had tried to force her into conversation, okay a little more believable, but not much. She's in college. Going to classes would be a lot worse for people with social anxiety.  Also, how do you undercook oatmeal? You put in hot water, then you wait. If it's not done after 30 seconds, microwaving it isn't going to 'cook' it faster. You just let it sit for a while. This may have worked if she was making Cup Ramen or something, but she could have taken it back to her room and let it sit for a few minutes just fine.   Aside from many glaring setting and subject issues, as a person with severe social anxiety, this game didn't speak to me at all.

Hm, I actually kind of liked this :D There's many decisions and many ways to fail at doing something as simple as creating oatmeal, which makes it entertaining to play around with and see all the different outcomes. Also, Samantha reminds me a lot of myself--painfully shy and awkward. I could totally see myself doing/saying half the things she does in this game x'D Lastly, I really like the art style, it's really cute C: All in all, I'd say this game deserves 6 spoons out of 10 ^-^
All I have to say is that I'm glad this was free... no thank you. Deleting immediately.
I swear the god I never met a person as single-handedly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ as Sam.

That is a girl I can relate to. While I don't got it near as bad, as she does. there are certinaly times and places that I totaly felt like that, and it seems everyone else is having a blast.   As for the game it self, is a short but well made game, it's like a Visual Novel but the story does actualy change with what decistions are made in the game. I would like to see more games on Samantha's adventures, I'd even be willing to a little for the episodes.  Last thing I'd like to comment on, with her beeing frustrated about how loud the microwave is, I've sure been there, but what I do to make them less noisy is watch when the time is low and open the door when there is a second or two left that way you still get 99.99% of the cook time but since it never hit zero it doesn't get all noisy, then you can just hit the cancel button and it's just like you microwaved it for the right amout of time and no loud beeping.

This is a charming little slice of life adventure game about the challenges of living in a dorm. I am not sure if there are multiple paths, but i suspect the experience is more about the narrative than the choices you make. The art is bold and the audio works well to build tension when it's warranted. I played it while i was waiting for a couple other games to download, and it is perfect for that. The emotions will likely be familiar to many who have had to share accommodation in the past, but even for those who've never experienced this sort of anxiety, this game gives a fun and friendly way to build empathy. Very good.

And damn, I have huge anxiety issues, but if I cared as much about others' opinions as she does, I'd have gone ♥♥♥♥ing bonkers. Also I resent that I failed because of the keys. Also I'm pretty sure I killed the Samantha chick when I accidentally made her return to the room empty-handed. Like there was literally some intense dimming of light going on. So dramatic. As someone who actually has social anxiety I can relate to most of this.  I think most of the really negative reviews are from people who are simply not capable of understanding how it feels and how having this 'disorder' can affect someone's life. For me it was interesting and funny when I realized I would make the same mistakes and feel the same way in that situation.  That being said, this is a very short... ehm... visual novel? And I do understand how the story can be a little boring for someone who can not relate in any way. Keep in mind though that it's free to play. Just give it a try and realize that you have lost absolutely nothing if you end up disliking it.
This is a short and visually nice looking game. I think many people with anxiety can relate to this.  I enjoyed it :)

If you want a cute little interactive story that gives a spotlight to what it's like to live with social anxiety, than this is a great choice. Not to mention, it's free, so how much can you really complain?  I enjoyed this quite a bit! Very cute art, and a very relatable story. I see other reviews on this criticizing and moaning that Samantha is a whiny baby, but I really appreciate how the writing captures social anxiety. I really likes this so much because when you have social anxiety, everything you do that involves or could involve people really seems like a quest, and I think it makes for a great set-up for a game. It makes me sad that the neg reviewers can't understand that Sam isn't just whining over nothing. It might seem like just going down the hall to make yourself food isn't a big deal at all, but that's the point: to some people, socially anxious people, it can be. I give the people who made this game lots of kudos, and I would love to see more Average Everyday Adventures in the future.

Cutting to the chase: this is a 15-20 minute game about a college girl making oatmeal. And I enjoyed this game. It's really visually cute, short, and sweet. I'm disappointed in the negative reviews it's getting. People seem to be missing the mark on what this game is about. It's not about Samantha being 'pretentious' or 'quirky and awkward', it's about her having social anxiety, especially within communal living. I, for one, like how it doesn't blow this fact out of proportion and shove it down your throat. If you know what to look for, the game's theme is pretty clear and I think elegantly displayed by the devs. Having social anxiety, yes, every average day is an adventure, because the outcomes are never clear to the person experiencing it, while others can simply stroll through the average day without much fuss or insecurity.  I would recommend a play, even just for the experience of something not everyone experiences. And really, taking a risk on a game that's less than 30 minutes long and is also free is really not too much too ask for, is it?

I enjoyed this quick, comfortable looking but delicately empathy provoking game. I am not the most social person, so it was easy for me to sympathize with Samantha's social anxiety even when it massively outstripped my own. Spending a little time with that level of stress helped me imagine what it might be like to live with that mindset on a day to day basis. Hats off to the developers for this educational and enjoyable experience. I look forward to Samantha's next adventure!

I'd like to start by saying I completely sympathise with this character. I did exactly the same thing myself. While the subject matter may be interesting, unique even, that does not excuse the arbitrary, unpredictable outcomes of your choices, and I personally feel the game is incompleteable without a guide. I tried multiple times and got stuck on the same two game over screens without understanding where I was failing.  It's a nice try at a relateable, meaningful story, and it's free, but it relies on repetative failures for you to learn what the character will do and how earlier descisions make the game impossible to win later. In short, I want to like it, but it simply isn't fun. If you want the acheivements, you'll be playing through the game 10 times, and while holding Ctrl speeds this up, it is still a massive bore.  I beleive this would have been a better game if it were more linier, with failures taking you back to the last descision, rather than the beginning of the game (more or less). In retrospect it feels as though that choice was made to pad the game length. That said, the art is lovely and it IS free, so you lose nothing by giving it a go (and if you don't want that to go against your acheivement percentage, you can just remove the licence from your account).
